Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Greetings all,
>
>	Just to let you know that the reason I've been a bit quiet lately is 
>I was busy finding myself a new job.
>
>	That's all done now, and I started with this lot: 
>http://www.navisworks.com/ on Tuesday.  So far they seem unreasonably nice :)
>  
>
Well good luck with that, looks 'your cup of tea' anyway. I looked for 
work this time last year but was thoroughly disheartened by the type of 
work available. At least my current job allows me to go off on 'flights 
of fancy' as far as coding is concerned - somehow I'm protected from 
commercial realtities by the umpteen layers of management between me and 
the shareholders :)

>	w.r.t SLEAT, I spent some time putting a ES-style (*) variance 
>parameters into it.  They don't seem to make much difference to the 
>search, but that mean they are not killing it either.  And they are 
>driven down to low values in old (and hence required) genes...  I put 
>them on all weights and also all FIDs.
>  
>
I woud expect this. The benefit should come from very long duration 
searches where the algorithm has time to settle on good variance parameters.

>	(*do I mean ES?  I get abbreviation blindness sometimes)
>  
>
Yeh I think that's right. These days Wikipedia has some info on these 
terms, but to be honest I think we need throw away all of these old 
terms and replace them with a proper classification system, since (to me 
anyway) all of these strategies are just variations on a theme.

>	Generally, SLEAT runs fine up to the point where the PPS fitness 
>(see my previous discussions) reaches about 90%.  Then it really 
>starts to slow (never quite stopping, but how would I know...) and by 
>the time it gets to around 92% the search is so slow that it becomes 
>impractical to continue...
>
>	How does that gel with folk's experience on similar problems?
>
Generally speaking I can confirm this observation. I think in your case 
the evaluation time is constant and it's the increasing complexity of 
the solutions that consumes time, yes? which is how I arrived at the 
phased pruning idea.

As for me I've started redesigning sharpneat with a fresh slate using 
generics (templates). So far so good. At the most abstract level I have 
an IEvolutionAlgorithm interface that defines the concept of an 
algorithm with generations and actring on completely abstract genome and 
phenome types. My current NEAT code then sits on top of this (with a 
couple of design layers in between) quite nicely and acts as a default 
implementation right now to put some meat on the bones of the framework. 
I then intend to create a completely new genome representation based on 
many of the ideas on the group over the last year.

I have to say that working with templates is a breath of fresh air, I 
think this new framework is going to make the old one look positively 
old hat!


>p.s. and a happy new year.
>  
>
Likewise.

Colin.
